body:
`readfile()` is a very important but mastodont-like function (1762 lines) at the moment of speaking. I've been trying to make more sense of it, but its structure is a bit hard to follow. Among other things because it likes to use internal goto's. I have no problem with goto's but in a 1762-line function it's a bit much.

So I had the idea of chopping it down to make it more understandable. One small win was that (I think) we can remove the parts that reference `try_mac` and `MACOS_CONVERT` since we don't support MacOS 9. That said, some people might want to edit files from that era, so I'm not sure if this would be broadly supported.

But extracting some functionality into functions would help readability and not impair functionality.

Thoughts?

comment_data.body:
I've got a start on that if anyone wants to cherry pick. https://github.com/splinterofchaos/neovim/tree/fileio

I also tried factoring some of the parts into smaller functions, but the issue is that even the smallest blocks of code might relate to five or more stateful variables.

I believe a good refactoring will be necessary in order to close #1008, largely because of how difficult it is to make sense of, and thus understand how changing parts will impact the whole.

On one hand, OS 9 was discontinued in 2001, so, about 15 years will have passed when neovim hits mainstream, if it does. I think lack of support for it wouldn't be much of a problem.

On the other hand, a text editor should do one thing well: editing text. And text can come in many encodings.

I think my take on this would be:
- Core editor should just support unicode, and choose one of its encodings (probably utf8) to work internally.*
- Hooks should be left wherever necessary, so that plugins can easily implement encoders/decoder to/from other encodings.

(*) Here I have doubts about leaving open the possibility for all encodings of unicode.

> 've got a start on that if anyone wants to cherry pick. https://github.com/splinterofchaos/neovim/tree/fileio

I really like those commits. Since I don't believe we'll be doing this in one swoop, we can start with the work you have in that branch. Is this already a PR?

> On one hand, OS 9 was discontinued in 2001, so, about 15 years will have passed when neovim hits mainstream, if it does. I think lack of support for it wouldn't be much of a problem.

Yea, I'm ambivalent as well. Perhaps if the support could be made a little less messy than it is now. I dislike the structure of the current `readfile` so I was looking for some quick wins, perhaps too eagerly.

> Is [the branch] already a PR?

Nope. Though, I just rebased and ran travis. Everything passes except that clang complains about uninitialized variables. Will look into in a bit. https://travis-ci.org/splinterofchaos/neovim/jobs/39768550#L587

Thoughts: lines 1502 to 1557 checks for bad UTF-8 bytes (and some other things), which basically already happens in mbyte.c in a few places. It can be extracted with some effort. The "some other things" are definitely a problem.

Fixed the problems spotted by clang. A variable can't be uninitialized when `goto fail` wants to free it.

> There must be a reason, but why not reuse buffer?

Lack of a `verbose_try_realloc()`?

> Lack of a verbose_try_realloc()?

That could be a reason, but one could still reuse an old `buffer` even without reallocating, if I'm not mistaken. Still deciphering the "sizing" part, but it seems as if it just takes the max it can get (from 64K downwards), so the first succesfull `buffer` should be the largest one available anyhow.

The decoding part of the `readfile()` function seems to duplicate a whole lot of functionality that's also present in `mbyte.c`. I'm dying to know _why_ that is.

I mean, sure, `readfile()` intersperses file reading logic with decoding logic, but it should be possible to decouple that. (and even cleanup `mbyte.c` a little while we're at it, though it's already way cleaner than `fileio.c`).

Also relevant is this SO question: http://stackoverflow.com/a/19795855/558819, I cite:

> Vim can handle large files pretty well. I just edited a 3.4GB file, deleting lines, etc. Three things to keep in mind:
> - Press Ctrl-C: Vim tries to read in the whole file initially, to do things like syntax highlighting and number of lines in file, etc. Ctrl-C will cancel this enumeration (and the syntax highlighting), and it will only load what's needed to display on your screen.
> - Readonly: Vim will likely start read-only when the file is too big for it to make a . file copy to perform the edits on. I had to w! to save the file, and that's when it took the most time.
> - Go to line: Typing :115355 will take you directly to line 115355, which is much faster going in those large files. Vim seems to start scanning from the beginning every time it loads a buffer of lines, and holding down Ctrl-F to scan through the file seems to get really slow near the end of it.

And then several uses claiming ctrl+c worked miracles for them and others claiming it only loads the file partially (which is what I would expect). I really wonder where this comes from, haven't been able to determine all the relevant parts for that in the source.
I blogged about part of my experiences, more upcoming: http://www.aktau.be/2014/11/04/neovim-input-encoding-and-you/

Great reading! When converting `fill_input_buf` to `convert_input` i didnt dive so deep into the related input-conversion code, great work.

As for the early merges, I know sometimes they can be inconvenient but I have to do it for rushing to the first release(which is much later than expected).  Keeping big changes in private branches will lead to poorer testing by users, and since nvim is still in alpha state I believe that making users try alpha-quality code is something we have flexibility to do

> As for the early merges, I know sometimes they can be inconvenient but I have to do it for rushing to the first release(which is much later than expected). Keeping big changes in private branches will lead to poorer testing by users, and since nvim is still in alpha state I believe that making users try alpha-quality code is something we have flexibility to do

I worded it quite poorly in that article, in the end I believe it to be quite a positive thing and I also advocate to keep doing it while we're in alpha and beta.

> On second thought, perhaps premature merging is not quite right, in a quickly moving project like Neovim it might actually be required to jumpstart a discussion after a lull.

By this I meant that the word "premature" might not be quite right. It's not premature if it's necessary to get a discussion going and more people testing it.

Nice article.
Maybe a version of it could be added to the wiki. Would be wonderful having a sum-up of explorers' discoveries about code in the wiki.
Clearness of interspersed code and prose make me wish about literate programming, too. ;-)

Thanks! A link to the article could be added to the wiki (I just updated the article itself and keeping it in sync with the wiki would be cumbersome). I promise not to let my site go offline (it's on github too). Currently working on my article about file encoding.
@aktau BTW, I don't know if you have realized it, but the article is already on hackernews. And there is one comment you will probably want to answer. ;-)

> @aktau BTW, I don't know if you have realized it, but the article is already on hackernews. And there is one comment you will probably want to answer. ;-)

Uh-oh, didn't expect this to reach HN. Unfortunately, my anti-procrastination settings prevent me from answering at the moment. octo_t has the right idea of course. It's new code that's calling into old, unrefactored code. Hence the casts. `convert_input` is new, `string_convert_ext` is old.
I know, I know. It's people reading that who don't know. Ok, don't worry. I just wanted to make sure you knew about the article having been published there.
There, I lamely worked around noprocrast and tried to give some responses :).
Nothing here that needs tracking.

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: simplify readfile() et al, extract into functions, remove MACOS_CONVERT
